DOC.HEAD: Premier Announces Reforms in Security Forces
With AM-Czechoslovakia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Premier Marian Calfa said Tuesday all domestic operations of the dreaded secret police have been halted. ``It is one of our priorities to adjust the work of the Interior Ministry to the new social conditions and turn this ministry into a component of state administration based on democratic principles,'' Calfa told Parliament, outlining his domestic and foreign policies. ``I can tell you that as of today the operations of the police force in the field of internal intelligence have been stopped,'' Calfa said. In 41 years of Communist rule, secret police agents were involved in continuous surveillance operations against citizens and were responsible for the interrogation and harassment of dissidents and independent thinkers. Opposition leader Vaclav Havel, once a dissident playwright and now the leading contender for president, has spoken about the constant threat of a house search; that every visitor to his home was photographed; and every conversation bugged by the Communist regime. Havel's house in downtown Prague was continuously monitored from a nearby tower, and cameras were installed by the secret police in other streets where dissidents lived. Police have been the target of public anger since they broke up a peaceful student rally Nov. 17, igniting the pro-democracy revolution that ended Communist domination. ``The police action in the streets of Prague has shaken the faith of citizens in the police force ... the government is taking steps to prevent the abuse of security forces against the people of this country,'' Calfa said. A parliamentary commission is investigating the crackdown. The new government, the country's first non-Communist-dominated Cabinet in 41 years, does not include an interior minister, responsible for all branches of the police including the secret force. Instead, those functions have been assumed by a three-man committee consisting of Calfa and two deputy premiers. Despite the move to control the secret police, opposition members and students, fearing a coverup of past misdeeds, have been patrolling police offices and police archives to prevent the destruction of incriminating documents. Activists in Brno reported last week that police documents were being burned, including documents from the 1950s and others bearing the names of well-known dissidents.
